obr
Class AtomConjunction

java.lang.Object
  obr.AtomConjunction
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Iterable<Atom>
Direct Known Subclasses:
AtomicRule
public class AtomConjunction
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Iterable<Atom>

Represents a conjunction of atoms.

Internal structure :
The internal structure is a biparted graph where edges are implemented by neighbours lists.
The first partition of vertices represents the atoms. Only their predicates are stored into this partition. But the vertex class provides a global ID which will can be used to identify an atom.
The second partition represents the terms. A term may be either a variable or a constant. Since terms are also stored into vertices, they have a global ID.
The edges are used to connect atoms with terms. And their value is the position of the term inside the atom. A well-built atom conjunction will ensure that there is one edge for each position of each atom predicate and that they are added in their position ordering.

About IDs :
Each vertex (thus, each atom and each term) has a different ID, which can be get by Vertex.getID() method. But since the internal structure provides a bipartition, atoms can be enumerated from 0 to getNbAtoms()-1, and terms from 0 to getNbTerms()-1.
To convert a global ID to a local one apply the following computation :

  • if atom : local ID = global ID
  • if term : local ID = global ID - getNbAtoms()

_graph

protected moca.graphs.BipartedGraph<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Integer> _graph
The structure of the atom conjunction.
The first vertices partition is used to store atoms (the vertices contain only predicates). And the second one to store terms. An edge represents a connection between an atom and a term, and its value the position of the term in the atom.

getAtom

public Atom getAtom(int i)
             throws java.util.NoSuchElementException
Creates a new atom instance for the atom whose id matches i.
The structure does not contain atom instances, that is why only a new instance can be generated. Furthermore, any modifications on this atom instance will NOT be applied on the atom representation in the conjunction.

Parameters:
i - The id of the atom.
Returns:
A new instance of atom class.
Throws:
java.util.NoSuchElementException - If the id does not match in the atom conjunction.

fromString

protected void fromString(java.lang.String str)
                   throws UnrecognizedStringFormatException
Fullfills the atom conjunction from its string representation.
The string must be under the following format (otherwise an exception will be thrown) : <atom 0>ATOM_SEPARATOR<atom 1>ATOM_SEPARATOR...ATOM_SEPARATOR<atom n> Where atoms must be under the following format : <predicate label>BEGIN_TERM_LIST<term 0>TERM_SEPARATOR<term 1>TERM_SEPARATOR...TERM_SEPARATOR <term m>END_TERM_LIST
The predicate labels and arity are used to check their equality, and only labels for terms equality.

Parameters:
str - The atom conjunction under a string format.
Throws:
UnrecognizedStringFormatException - Whenever the string passed as parameter does not follow a good format.

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Converts the atom conjunction into a String format.
Note that this is just a convenient method for toString(getNbAtoms()).

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object
Returns:
A well-formatted string representation.
See Also:
toString(int)

toString

public java.lang.String toString(int nbAtoms)
Converts a subset of the atom conjunction into a String format.
Only atoms whose id is between 0 and the parameter will be converted. This method is usefull for inheritance which specializes some of atoms.

Parameters:
nbAtoms - The number of atoms to be converted.

addAtom

public int addAtom(Predicate predicate)
Adds an atom into the atom conjunction.
The internal representation of an atom is a graph vertex with predicate value, that is why only a predicate is needed.

Parameters:
predicate - The predicate of the new atom.
Returns:
The global index of the new atom in the conjunction.

addTerm

public int addTerm(Term term)
Adds a term into the atom conjunction.
Note that the term will not be connected to any atom. Use addEdge method to make these connections.
Furthermore, if the term is already in the conjunction, no new term will be added.

Parameters:
term - The new term to add.
Returns:
The term index.

addTerm

public int addTerm(java.lang.String termLabel)
Adds a term into the atom conjunction from its label.

Parameters:
termLabel - The new term label to add.
Returns:
The term index.
See Also:
addTerm(Term)

addEdge

public boolean addEdge(int atomID,
                       int termID,
                       java.lang.Integer position)
Adds an edge between an atom and a term.
If the arity of the atom id is n, then the position must be in [0;n-1].

Parameters:
atomID - The id of the atom to connect.
termID - The id of the term to connect.
position - The position of the term in the atom.
Returns:
True if success, false otherwise.

subAtomConjunction

public AtomConjunction subAtomConjunction(int beginAtomID,
                                          int endAtomID)
Returns a new atom conjunction which is a clone of a subset of the current atom conjunction.
The two parameters will be used as the range of atoms to be used. All terms connected to one of these atoms will also be added into the clone. Thus, all edges which were connected to the atoms in the current atom conjunction will also be present in the clone.
Note that the first atom will be included but not the last. I.e., if this method is used on 0,getNbAtom(), all the atom conjunction will be cloned.

Parameters:
beginAtomID - The ID of the first atom (included).
endAtomID - The ID of the last atom (not included).
Returns:
The new atom conjunction if the parameters are not absurds, false otherwise.

cloneIn

public AtomConjunction cloneIn(AtomConjunction copy)
Clones the atom conjunction into a copy instance.

copy - The instance where to clone.

The clone.
